title: How to Make Mofongo

steps.headline: Heat the vegetable oil.
steps.description: Heat about an inch or two (2.5cm - 5cm) height of oil in a deep frying pan or wok to 350ºF/180ºC. If you don't have a thermometer, heat the oil until you can place a slice of plantain into the pan and it immediately starts bubbling as it fries.

steps.headline: Peel the plantains.
steps.description: Make a shallow cut along one of the lengthwise "ribs" of the plantain and carefully peel the skin by inserting your fingertip at one end and running it down the banana. It will also be easier if you soak the plantain in hot water for no more than two or three minutes to soften the skin.

steps.headline: Slice the plantain across its width into one-inch (2.5cm) round slices.
Fry the plantain slices in batches until they are golden yellow.
steps.description: Do not fry them too much; if they turn brown they may not have the right consistency. You want them cooked through, not toasted.

steps.headline: Set the fried pieces in a bowl lined with paper towels to drain and dry.
Place four or five pieces of fried plantain in the pilón (wooden mortar and pestle) and mash them.
steps.description: Add a couple of garlic cloves, a few pieces of pork rind (the idea is to make it a little crunchy without overpowering the taste), a tablespoon of olive oil, and salt and pepper to taste into the pilón. Mash the mixture again. Alternatively, you can use a food processor with a cutting blade, though the consistency of the finished product will not be the same and may require a bit more olive oil.

steps.headline: Remove the mixture from the pilón and shape it into a half-ball (round with a flat bottom).

tyn: A deep frying pan to fry the plantains. A wok is perfect for this!
Paper towels to dry the fried plantains, and a bowl

A "Pilón" -- a wooden mortar and pestle, available at any supermarket that sells Caribbean cooking utensils. You can use one made out of marble, ceramic or similar hard material, but it's easier to mash the plantains if you use a wooden one because they stick better to the sides of the pilon's bowl. If you do not have access to a pilón, a food processor with a cutting blade is acceptable as an alternative.
sentences: Heat the vegetable oil.
Heat about an inch or two (2.5cm - 5cm) height of oil in a deep frying pan or wok to 350ºF/180ºC.
If you don't have a thermometer, heat the oil until you can place a slice of plantain into the pan and it immediately starts bubbling as it fries.
Peel the plantains.
Make a shallow cut along one of the lengthwise "ribs" of the plantain and carefully peel the skin by inserting your fingertip at one end and running it down the banana.
It will also be easier if you soak the plantain in hot water for no more than two or three minutes to soften the skin.
Slice the plantain across its width into one-inch (2.5cm) round slices.
Fry the plantain slices in batches until they are golden yellow.
Do not fry them too much; if they turn brown they may not have the right consistency.
You want them cooked through, not toasted.
Set the fried pieces in a bowl lined with paper towels to drain and dry.
Place four or five pieces of fried plantain in the pilón (wooden mortar and pestle) and mash them.

Add a couple of garlic cloves, a few pieces of pork rind (the idea is to make it a little crunchy without overpowering the taste), a tablespoon of olive oil, and salt and pepper to taste into the pilón.
Mash the mixture again.
Alternatively, you can use a food processor with a cutting blade, though the consistency of the finished product will not be the same and may require a bit more olive oil.
Remove the mixture from the pilón and shape it into a half-ball (round with a flat bottom).
If you will be serving it by itself, you're done!
Just add to a serving plate along with salad, mains, etc.
